title: What are the best universities in Europe? - Quora

response.answer_text: All of you who ponder on the idea of studying abroad should definitely consider a country from Europe, even if you’re a European yourself. Why? Because Europe is one of the oldest continents, each country is quite unique, steeped in history, and there is always something new and interesting to discover, regardless of the study destination you will choose. The UK boasts Europe’s highest number of internationally ranked universities with 84 entries, followed by Germany (46) and France (31). However, it’s Switzerland that joins the UK in having a university ranked among the world’s top 10, something neither Germany nor France can manage.  Top universities in Austria A landlocked country in central Europe, Austria shares borders with eight other European nations, including Germany to the north and Italy to the south. University of Vienna (joint 154th in the world, joint 64th in Europe)Vienna University of Technology (joint 192nd in the world, joint 84th in Europe)Universität Innsbruck (joint 266th in the world, 115th in Europe)Technische Universität Graz (311th in the world, 136th in Europe)Johannes Kepler University Linz (joint 412th in the world, joint 183rd in Europe)Top universities in Belgium Known for its fine chocolate and beer, Belgium is also home to some excellent educational establishments. This year it claims eight of the top universities in Europe to be internationally ranked, with all but two of these placed within the top 300 worldwide. KU Leuven (80th in the world, 26th in Europe)Ghent University (joint 130th in the world, joint 51st in Europe)Université Catholique de Louvain (UCL)(joint 167th in the world, 70th in Europe)Vrije Universiteit Brussel (VUB)(195th in the world, 87th in Europe)University of Antwerp (223rd in the world, 96th in Europe)Top universities in France France boasts a very extensive selection of top European universities, and an impressive presence in the international rankings, with the majority of its top 10 universities located in the capital city Paris. Paris Sciences et Lettres Research University (PSL) (53rd in the world, 13th in Europe)Ecolé Polytechnique (joint 60th in the world, 15th in Europe)Sorbonne University (77th in the world, 23rd in Europe)CentraleSupélec(139th in the world, 55th in Europe)Ecole Normale Supérieure de Lyon(joint 160th in the world, 66th in Europe)Top universities in Germany Offering free tuition to undergraduate students in all but one state, Germany is one of the world’s most popular non-Anglophone destinations for international students. Technische Universität München (55th in the world, 14th in Europe)Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München (63rd in the world, 17th in Europe)Ruprecht-Karls-Universität Heidelberg(66th in the world, 19th in Europe)Humboldt-Universität Zu Berlin (joint 120th in the world, joint 44th in Europe)Kit, Karlsruher Institut Für Technologie (124th in the world, 47th in Europe)Top universities in Ireland A relatively small country in Western Europe, Ireland is home to eight world-ranking universities, of which half are in the capital city, Dublin. Trinity College Dublin(joint 108th in the world, 37th in Europe)University College Dublin(185th in the world, 80th in Europe)The National University of Ireland, Galway(259th in the world, 112th in Europe)University College Cork(310th in the world, 135th in Europe)Dublin City University(joint 429th in the world, joint 189th in Europe)Top universities in Italy Located in the southern peninsula of the continent and much-loved for its weather, cuisine and beautiful settings, Italy is the fifth most populous country in Europe and boasts 34 internationally ranked universities. Politecnico di Milano(149th in the world, 61st in Europe)Scuola Superiore Sant'Anna Pisa (joint 177th in the world, joint 75th in Europe)University of Bologna (UNIBO) (joint 177th in the world, joint 75th in Europe)The Sapienza University of Rome (203rd in the world, 89th in EuropeScuola Normale Superiore di Pisa(204th in the world, 90th in Europe)Top universities in the Netherlands This Dutch-speaking country towards the north of the continent boasts 13 globally ranked universities. Delft University of Technology(50th in the world, 13th in Europe)University of Amsterdam(64th in the world, 15th in Europe)Eindhoven University of Technology(102nd in the world, 35th in Europe)University of Groningen (114th in the world, 40th in Europe)Leiden University(118th in the world, 42nd in Europe)Top universities in the Nordic countries Europe’s Nordic countries (Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden) offer 27 internationally ranked universities. Within the Nordic region, Finland claims the highest number of ranked institutions, despite being the most sparsely populated country in Europe, while Denmark offers the highest-ranked university in the group. Top universities in the UK Second, only to the US in the number of total universities included in the ranking, the UK is the most popular destination to study in Europe (although Brexit may change this in the future). It currently boasts four of the world’s top 10 universities and eight of the 10 top universities in Europe. University of Oxford(fourth in the world, first in Europe)The University of Cambridge(seventh in the world, third in Europe)UCL (University College London)(eighth in the world, fourth in Europe)Imperial College London(ninth in the world, fifth in Europe)University of Edinburgh(20th in the world, seventh in Europe)The list above covers most of the best-known places to study in Europe as an international student. But the top European universities do not end there. Many more European countries are home to one or more institutions included in the QS World University Rankings.

A lot of answers to this question quote international rankings, which is a very dangerous game to play if you let it play a role in deciding where to study for a number of reasons Depending on the ranking, education may only be a small part of the assessment on which the ranking is based, so for using it as guide on where to study may not be ideal. For example several of the so-called little Ivy league schools in the US do not have a graduate program and as a consequence do almost no research (which would cost them a lot of points in some rankings), but in terms of teaching they are very good (and within the US quite competitive to get into).In some rankings reputation is taken into account, making the rankings self-enforcingInternational exposure is a large part of the ranking criteria, which means that in terms of actual academic achievement, universities in countries like Germany and France, which have a much stronger tendency to hold on to the local language (in France it is actively encouraged), are undervalued. For the same reason US and UK institutions are overvalued.More specialist places of higher learning can be undervalued (e.g. technical universities), in particular when ‘completeness’ of the curriculum is part of the ranking criteria. This is even applicable to e.g. Imperial College, which has no humanities department.Beyond the top 20, the differences within the rankings become marginal and a university at 50th place will not be much better than the one at 100th. Rankings that are field specific would be a better guide to distinguish.The best approach is to chose a school of solid reputation with a teaching philosophy that fits you best and do well.
